title.narrative: DEMAND FOR IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS ON CHILD FEEDING AND CARE PRACTICES

description.narrative: By 2020, women and caregivers are equipped with the knowledge and skills for improved child feeding and care practices, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Early Childhood Development, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition (Covid), Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Children and women in vulnerable regions demand and use high-quality and proven preventive and curative nutrition interventions, including in emergency situations.

sector.narrative: Breastfeeding protection, promotion and support (including work on Code)
Care for children with severe acute malnutrition
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition
Diet diversity in early childhood (children under 5), includes complementary feeding and MNPs
National multisectoral strategies and plans to prevent stunting (excludes intervention-specific strategies)
Social and behavioural change communication for ECD
Technical assistance - Prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, women and caregivers are equipped with the knowledge and skills for improved child feeding and care practices

description.narrative: The main strategy for IYCF programming was counselling on child feeding and care practices which has facilitated knowledge and skills improvement of women and caregivers of children aged 0–23 months. In 2021,390,150persons have received key IYCF messages. During the programme cycle, almost2,237,531have benefited from IYCF programmes through multiple platforms used by trained and equipped health and voluntary community workers. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:01/02/2022
